case_name: D. R. Nim v. Government of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 371 of 1965 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 8, 1961 of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 507-D of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 371 of 1965- Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 8, 1961 of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Writ No, 507-D of 1961.

facts.text: The Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi dismissed the petition under art. 226 filed by the appellant D. R. Nim in limine.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi, dismissing in limine the petition under art. 226 of the Constitution filed by the appellant, D. R. Nim.

facts.text: The appellant impugned an order dated August 25, 1955 passed by the Government of India, Ministry of Home Affairs.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had impugned in this petition an order dated August 25, 1955, passed by the Government of India,  Ministry of Home Affairs -hereinafter referred to as the impugned order-as being companytrary to law and art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The appellant was appointed to the U.P. Police Service as a result of a competitive examination held in 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts for the determination of the validity of the impugned order are as follows The appellant was appointed to the U.P. Police Service as a result of a companypetitive examination held in 1938.

facts.text: The appellant was appointed officiating Superintendent of Police with effect from June 25, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: In companyrse of time he was appointed officiating Superintendent of Police with effect from June 25, 1947. He companytinued to officiate till he was appointed to the Indian Police Service against the promotion quota of the Indian Police Service Cadre of Uttar Pradesh with effect from October 22, 1955.

facts.text: The appellant continued to officiate as Superintendent of Police till appointed to the Indian Police Service against the promotion quota of the UP cadre with effect from October 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: He companytinued to officiate till he was appointed to the Indian Police Service against the promotion quota of the Indian Police Service Cadre of Uttar Pradesh with effect from October 22, 1955.

facts.text: Indian Police Service (Regulation of Seniority) Rules, 1954 were issued by the Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: By the time he was appointed to the Indian Police Service various Rules and Regulations governing the Indian Police Service had been issued by the Central Government in exercise of the powers companyferred by sub-s.  1  of s. 3 of the All India Services Act  LXI of 1951 .

facts.text: The appellant's seniority has to be determined under the Indian Police Service (Regulation of Seniority) Rules, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned particularly with the Indian Police Service  Regulation of Seniority  Rules, 1954, hereinafter referred to as the Seniority Rules. The seniority of the appellant has to be determined under these Seniority Rules.

facts.text: The appellant's name was included in the Select List of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants name was included in the Select List of 1956. Therefore, in the case of the appellant, the period prior to 1956 had to be approved by the Central Government in companysultation with the Commission.

facts.text: The impugned order dated August 25, 1955 states that State Civil Service Officers officiating prior to 19th May 1951 but appointed to IAS after that date get benefit of continuous officiation from May 19, 1951 for seniority.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India have number decided with the companycurrence of the Commission that the State Civil Service Officers who were officiating prior to 19th May, 1951, but have been appointed to the Indian Administrative Service after that date should, for purposes of fixation of seniority, be allowed the benefit of their companytinuous officiation in senior posts with effect from the 19th May, 1951.

facts.text: The same decision in impugned order applies to State Police Officers promoted to IPS after May 19, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The same decision will also apply in the case of State Police Officers promoted to the Indian Police Service after the 19th May, 1951.

facts.text: As per impugned order, appellant's officiation from June 25, 1947 to May 19, 1951 is excluded for seniority fixation.

anchor.surface_text: The result of this decision, as far as the appellant is companycerned, is that the period of officiation as Superintendent of Police from June 25, 1947 to May 19, 1951, is excluded for the purpose of fixation of seniority.

facts.text: Instructions issued vide Shri R. C. Duttâ€™s letter No. 1/18/51-AIS dated June 22, 1951 prescribing procedure for seniority and year of allotment.

anchor.surface_text: While recruitment to the Service through these diverse unconventional sources was being made over the years, the question of fixation of seniority and year of allotment was subseqently companysidered and instructions were issued vide Shri R. C. Dutts letter No. 1/18/51-AIS dated 22nd June, 1951 prescribing the detailed procedure as to how the seniority and the year of allotment of each officer and for each category of recruitment should be fixed.

facts.text: May 19, 1951 is the date when Gradation List for earlier IAS recruits was finalised.

anchor.surface_text: It was also felt that since 19th May, 1951 was the date on which the Gradation List for all the earlier persons recruited to the Service had been finalised and issued in a somewhat stable stage, this may be a crucial date, and officiation prior to which companyld be regarded as fortuitous.

facts.text: The decision on May 19, 1951 date was taken after consultation with State Governments and UPSC.

anchor.surface_text: It may be reiterated that this decision was taken after companysultation with the State Governments and the U.P.S.C.

facts.text: Government of India decided in consultation with Ministry of Law that letter dated August 25, 1955 not applicable to SCS/SPS officers appointed to IAS/IPS prior to IPS Seniority Rules 1954 and prior to that letter if earlier continuous officiation approved.

anchor.surface_text: It further appears from the affidavit of Mr. D. K, Guha, Deputy Secretary to the Government of India, Ministry of Home Affairs, dated December 9, 1966, that the Government of India have recently decided in companysultation with the Ministry of Law that the Ministry of Home Affairs letter No. 2/32/51-AIS, dated the 25th August, 1955, will number be applicable to those SCS SPS officers, who were a pointed to IAS IPS prior to the promulgation of IAS IPS  Regulation of Seniority  Rules, 1954, and the date of the issue of the above letter if their earlier companytinuous officiation was approved by the Ministry of Home Affairs and Union Public Service Commission.

facts.text: Shri C. S. Prasad, IPS officer of Bihar, given benefit of full continuous officiation and year of allotment revised.

anchor.surface_text: It further,appears that in the case of Shri C. S. Prasad also, an IPS officer of Bihar, a decision has been taken to give the benefit of full companytinuous officiation in senior posts and to revise his year of allotment accordingly.

facts.text: Appellant D. R. Nim appointed to IPS on October 22, 1955, after Seniority Rules 1954 and after August 25, 1955 letter.

anchor.surface_text: But, it is stated that as Shri Nim was appointed to IPS on the 22nd October, 1955, i.e. after the promulgation of IPS  Regulation of Seniority  Rules, 1954, and after the issue of letter dated 25-8-1955, his case does number fall even under this category.

facts.text: The court finds selection of May 19, 1951 as crucial date arbitrary and irrational.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. B. R. L. Iyengar, the learned companynsel for the appellant, strongly urges that selection of May 19, 1951, as a crucial date for classifying people is arbitrary and irrational. We agree with him in this respect.

facts.text: The fixing of May 19, 1951 as date prior to which officiation not counted is contrary to Rule 3 of Seniority Rules.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the fixing of an artificial date, like May 19, 1951, as the date prior to which period of officiation would number be deemed to be approved by the Central Government is companytrary to Rule 3.

facts.text: Appeal accepted on ground that May 19, 1951 date arbitrary and contrary to Rule 3.

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to decide this point because the appeal has to be accepted on the ground that the selection of May 19, 1951, as a ,crucial date for classifying people is arbitrary and companytrary to Rule 3.

facts.text: Government contends appellant's continuous officiation was temporary or local arrangement within Explanation 1 to Rule 3.

anchor.surface_text: We had earlier left open the point raised by the Government of ,India that the appellants companytinuous officiation was a temporary or local arrangement within Explanation 1 to Rule This is sought to be sustained by the following statement in the affidavit dated March 15, 1966

facts.text: Appellant denies that his officiation was a stop-gap arrangement due to shortage.

anchor.surface_text: This statement is denied by the appellant. We agree with him that such a stop-gap arrangement cannot last for eight years and it has number been shown that the appellant was appointed temporarily in place of some persons as subsequently he has never been reverted.

facts.text: Court agrees with appellant that stop-gap arrangement cannot last eight years and no reversion shown.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with him that such a stop-gap arrangement cannot last for eight years and it has number been shown that the appellant was appointed temporarily in place of some persons as subsequently he has never been reverted.

facts.text: Appellant officiated for eight years without reversion.

anchor.surface_text: such a stop-gap arrangement cannot last for eight years and it has number been shown that the appellant was appointed temporarily in place of some persons as subsequently he has never been reverted. Further the fact that he was appointed to the post at the time when vacancies fell negatives that it was merely a temporary arrangement.

issues.text: Whether the impugned order dated August 25, 1955 is contrary to law and Article 14 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: passed by the Government of India,  Ministry of Home Affairs -hereinafter referred to as the impugned order-as being contrary to law and art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: What is the correct procedure for assignment of year of allotment under Rule 3 of the Seniority Rules, particularly regarding approval of prior continuous officiation?

anchor.surface_text: The first thing to be done under the Seniority Rules is to determine the year of allotment of the appellant. The appellant claims that a wrong year of allotment has been given to him by the application of the impugned order

issues.text: Whether the selection of May 19, 1951 as a crucial date for classifying officers and excluding prior officiation is arbitrary, irrational and violative of Article 14?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. B. R. L. Iyengar, the learned counsel for the appellant, strongly urges that selection of May 19, 1951, as a crucial date for classifying people is arbitrary and irrational.

issues.text: On a proper construction of Rule 3 and its provisos, whether the entire period of continuous officiation prior to inclusion in the Select List must be counted towards year of allotment without specific approval?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Iyengar had contended before us that on a proper construction of the rules, the entire period of officiation in a senior post has to be counted towards the seniority of the appellant.

issues.text: Whether the letter dated August 25, 1955 is without legal authority and contrary to Rule 3 of the Seniority Rules?

anchor.surface_text: The next point Mr. Iyengar raised was that the letter dated August 25, 1955, was without any legal authority and was contrary to rules.

issues.text: Whether the appellant's continuous officiation in a senior post was merely a purely temporary or local stop-gap arrangement under Explanation 1 to Rule 3?

anchor.surface_text: We had earlier left open the point raised by the Government of India that the appellants continuous officiation was a temporary or local arrangement within Explanation 1 to Rule

issues.text: Whether the appellant has been treated unequally among equals without valid reason?

anchor.surface_text: The last point which Mr. Iyengar raised was that the appellant for no valid reason has been treated unequally among his equals.

holdings.text: Selection of May 19, 1951, as a crucial date for classifying people is arbitrary and irrational.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. B. R. L. Iyengar, the learned counsel for the appellant, strongly urges that selection of May 19, 1951, as a crucial date for classifying people is arbitrary and irrational. We agree with him in this respect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Date derived from IAS gradation list without adequate relevance to IPS; lacks rational basis for classification under Article 14.

holdings.text: The fixing of an artificial date like May 19, 1951, prior to which period of officiation would not be deemed approved by Central Government, is contrary to Rule 3 of Seniority Rules.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the fixing of an artificial date, like May 19, 1951, as the date prior to which period of officiation would not be deemed to be approved by the Central Government is contrary to Rule 3.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 3 mandates case-by-case approval of prior officiation by Central Government in consultation with Commission, not blanket cutoff date.

holdings.text: Impugned order dated August 25, 1955 is contrary to law, Rule 3, and Article 14; appeal allowed on this ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to decide this point because the appeal has to be accepted on the ground that the selection of May 19, 1951, as a crucial date for classifying people is arbitrary and contrary to Rule 3.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines arbitrariness under Art 14 with violation of Rule 3's requirement for individual approval, invalidating uniform exclusion of pre-1951 officiation.

holdings.text: Entire period of continuous officiation prior to Select List inclusion does not automatically count towards year of allotment; requires approval under Rule 3 second proviso.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Iyengar had contended before us that on a proper construction of the rules, the entire period of officiation in a senior post has to be counted towards the seniority of the appellant. We have already discussed this point above and, in our opinion, there is no force in this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 3 second proviso explicitly conditions counting of pre-Select List officiation on Central Government's approval in consultation with Commission.

holdings.text: Appellant's continuous officiation was not a purely temporary or local stop-gap arrangement under Explanation 1 to Rule 3.

anchor.surface_text: This statement is denied by the appellant. We agree with him that such a stop-gap arrangement cannot last for eight years and it has not been shown that the appellant was appointed temporarily in place of some persons as subsequently he has never been reverted. Further the fact that he was appointed to the post at the time when vacancies fell negatives that it was merely a temporary arrangement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Officiation lasted eight years without reversion or break, and occurred when vacancies existed, negating temporary nature.

justification_sets.label: IPS Seniority Rules Rule 3 Explanation 1 support

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to decide this point because the appeal has to be accepted on the ground that the selection of May 19, 1951, as a ,crucial date for classifying people is arbitrary and contrary to Rule 3.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Government of India's order dated August 25, 1955 held arbitrary, irrational and contrary to Rule 3 of IPS (Regulation of Seniority) Rules, 1954; fixation of May 19, 1951 as crucial date set aside.
directions: Central Government to consider all relevant facts including period of continuous officiation prior to inclusion in Select List, approve or disapprove in consultation with State Government and UPSC, and determine year of allotment ad hoc.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. B. R. L. Iyengar, the learned counsel for the appellant, strongly urges that selection of May 19, 1951, as a crucial date for classifying people is arbitrary and irrational. We agree with him in this respect.

It is not necessary to decide this point because the appeal has to be accepted on the ground that the selection of May 19, 1951, as a ,crucial date for classifying people is arbitrary and contrary to Rule 3.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Iyengar had contended before us that on a proper construction of the rules, the entire period of officiation in a senior post has to be counted towards the seniority of the appellant. We have already discussed this point above and, in our opinion, there is no force in this contention.

It is not necessary to decide this point because the appeal has to be accepted on the ground that the selection of May 19, 1951, as a ,crucial date for classifying people is arbitrary and contrary to Rule 3.

anchor.surface_text: This statement is denied by the appellant. We agree with him that such a stop-gap arrangement cannot last for eight years and it has not been shown that the appellant was appointed temporarily in place of some persons as subsequently he has never been reverted. Further the fact that he was appointed to the post at the time when vacancies fell negatives that it was merely a temporary arrangement.

It is not necessary to decide this point because the appeal has to be accepted on the ground that the selection of May 19, 1951, as a ,crucial date for classifying people is arbitrary and contrary to Rule 3.
